title: Ticket #7403: Knob DAGMan illegal character checking
description: In #5966 we prohibited the use of certain characters ('.', '+') in DAGMan node names because they created problems with the parser in splices. As it turned out, many people were using these characters in their workflows and this changed caused a lot of headache. Let's knob this behavior so that people can use illegal characters when they want, but prohibit them when necessary.
remarks:
2019-Dec-04 13:15:25 by coatsworth:
All done. The new knob is called DAGMAN_ALLOW_ANY_NODE_NAME_CHARACTERS and is set to false by default. Additionally we removed the period character (.) from the list of illegal characters.

2019-Dec-04 14:51:06 by coatsworth:
Also, I've figured out why we decided to disallow periods in the first place.

It has to do with submitting multiple dags at once and mungeing node names. If we were to submit multiple dags as follows:

condor_submit_dag mydag1.dag mydag2.dag

Then the parser prepends the dag number before the node names. So in mydag1.dag, a job called FirstJob gets munged to 0.FirstJob, SecondJob gets munged to 0.SecondJob. In mydag2.dag, FirstJob gets munged to 1.FirstJob and SecondJob gets munged to 1.SecondJob. This is described in more detail at https://htcondor.readthedocs.io/en/latest/users-manual/dagman-applications.html#single-submission-of-multiple-independent-dags.

So re-allowing the period opens up the possibility of name collisions. I think this is still safe. Not only are collisions very rare, but there are multiple workarounds: 1) don't submit multiple DAGs at once, 2) set the DAGMAN_MUNGE_NODE_NAMES macro to False, 3) if you must submit multiple DAGs at once, make sure they have unique node names.

2019-Dec-13 14:14:29 by johnkn:
CODE_REVIEW change looks ok. although a param_call is kind of expensive to be doing for each node name check.
